fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: The error that a commemoration next year will mark the 200th anniversary of the abolition of slavery in the British empire was repeated in a Comment article, A modern-day slavery is flourishing in Britain, and we just avert our eyes, page 25, yesterday. To reiterate, it was the trade in slaves from the empire that was abolished in 1807; slavery in Britain had been illegal after 1772 but it remained in the colonies until 1833. In our item, Sex, lies and heroin, page 30, December 16, we referred to the Home Office review on prostitution, Paying the Price, saying it was published "earlier this year". In fact, it was published in July 2004. Sir Nicholas Lyell (not Lyall), mentioned in our front-page lead, Saudi inquiry decision faces legal challenge, December 16, became Lord Lyell of Markyate in 2005. Schoenberg not Shoenberg, an interview with Tan Dun, page 7, Film & Music, December 15. Belisha beacons are named after Leslie Hore-Belisha, not Samuel Hore-Belisha (Simon Hoggart's week, page 20, December 16). Sir Colin Figures, whose obituary we carried on page 31, yesterday, died on December 8 this year, 2006. It appeared as 2007. Apologies. · It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number.
